p: ANOVA analyses showed that the warming treatment had significantly positive effects on the species richness of seedlings in the alpine meadow (Table 1, Figure 2). Averages of 15, 15.4, 18.8, and 16.6 species were found in C, G, W, and WG per plot (0.25Â m 2), respectively, and in total, 36 seedling species were recorded (Appendix S1). The diversity of the sexual recruitment seedlings was higher than that of asexual (Table 1, Figure 2). Grazing and the interactions between warming and grazing had no significant impact on plant richness. However, grazing reduced the effect of warming on seedling species richness, and sexual recruits accounted for 82% of the reduced species (Figure 2). Therefore, to generalize our findings, warming significantly increased the species diversity of the seedlings in the alpine meadows, while grazing reduced the response of the grasses to warming.
